div2.head: INTRODUCTORY REMARKS.
div2.p: ABUNDANT evidence exists, from history, that the ancients were fully aware of the great importance of using Pure Water. One circumstance alone—viz., the construction, at an enormous expense, of their magnificent Aqueducts—sufficiently attests the fact. We find likewise in old writings, that the vigour and florid appearance of the inhabitants, and healthiness of the animals living in a neighbourhood, were considered as depending greatly on the good quality of the water made use of; and that the pale and unhealthy appearance of goitre, or swellings of the neck, and other signs of disease, were ascribed to the use of unwholesome water. In our own times, also, we have no lack of evidence tending to show, most unequivocally, the value of having the water made use of for domestic purposes of the purest quality. Every one who has travelled in the Low Countries of Holland and Belgium, must be aware that the use of the water to those unaccustomed to it quickly gives rise to affections of the bowels, and to such an extent is this the case, that our guide-books warn travellers not to partake of it. The same applies to water derived from Marshy sources in our own country; and doubtless much of the epidemic diarrhoea so common in Great Britain and other countries in summer and autumnal months, may with justice be ascribed to the increased impurities of water at such seasons, caused by the heat of the weather. Not only does the use of Impure water give rise to diseases of a slight character, and such as are slow in their action, but during the prevalence of different epidemics the liability to be affected appears to be very considerably influenced by the quality of the water made use of. This is shown by Dr. Snow in his pamphlet, “On the Mode of Communication of Cholera;” and to show that such is not merely an individual opinion, we need only refer for confirmation of the fact to the Report of the General Board of Health, on the Epidemic Cholera, of 1848-49, where the following passage occurs:—“During the late epidemic, much additional evidence has been elicited, proving the influence of the use of Impure water in predisposing to the disease. There has been scarcely a town in the kingdom in which cholera has been prevalent, that has not afforded some instance of it; and where the water has been contaminated by the contents of sewers or privies, or by the drainage of graveyards, the seizures have been more sudden and violent, and the proportion of deaths to attacks greater even than from overcrowding.” Many cases are given as confirmations of the truth of this assertion, and proved to apply not only to cholera, but to typhus and malignant scarlet fever, agues, and other fatal diseases. The accounts of long voyages not unfrequently give striking evidence of the terrible effects of Impure water made use of on board ships, arising from the decomposition of animal and vegetable matters contained in it, all of which may be effectually removed by very simple means. Occasionally, disease may be produced by the water made use of for domestic purposes becoming impregnated with metallic impurities not originally contained in it, but arising from the tanks and pipes in which it remains, and through which it passes. Want of room and not of matter prevents the entering more fully upon this subject, but enough has been given to show that if, as has been asserted by many physicians, Pure water is the fittest drink for persons of all ages and temperaments, it may with equal truth be said, that Impure water is one of the fruitful sources of disease.

Few persons are aware of the great number of living animals, and the mass of putrid animal and vegetable matter contained in the water drawn from wells supplied from land springs; or in that obtained from lakes, ponds, or brooks, making the water disagreeable to the taste, smell, and sight, and engendering disease.

The inhabitants of the large towns and cities of Great Britain generally receive the water they drink, and use for culinary purposes, from the rivers that flow through or near the towns in which they dwell. The water from these rivers not only contains the deleterious substances found in wells and ponds, but is also contaminated with the Sewage from the drains, the refuse of chemical works, and a thousand other nuisances. Should any one be disposed to doubt the statements made, they will find them fully borne out by the evidence given by the most eminent medical and scientific men before the General Board of Health; and by the record of the Analytical Sanitary Commission, given in the Lancet, February, 1851. It is from this source the annexed engravings are copied, reduced to nearly half the size.
This engraving shows the more remarkable animal and vegetable productions found in the water of the Thames at Waterloo Bridge, magnified 140 diameters.

This is the state of the Thames water at a part of the river where the contents of the large sewers of the metropolis become mixed with the fluid. Dr. Hassall in his examination states, “that the great amount of animal life present in the water of the Thames near the bridges, is directly dependent on the organic matter contained in it which is derived principally from the Sewer water daily poured into the river, the animalculæ finding in it the means of subsistence and growth.”

Though the Thames is most contaminated as it flows through the more densely inhabited part of the metropolis, yet long before it reaches London it contains an abundance of animal and vegetable matter, as may be seen in the annexed engraving (Fig. 2), representing the principal objects in a drop of water taken from the Thames at Richmond. Magnified 140 diameters.

These engravings can only represent the substances found in the water; the putrid animal and vegetable matters that infect the fluid, although invisible, combine to make us concur in the evidence taken by the Commissioners, “that the Thames from Kew to Woolwich is in a state unfitted for human consumption;” and the same remark applies to the water obtained from the Lea, the Brent, and other sources.

The source of the New River is at Amwell, in Hertfordshire. Thence it winds its slow stream to the metropolis, receiving additions on its way from the Lea and other streams. The distance of Amwell from London by the road is about twenty-two miles, but the length of the river is nearly double that number of miles. It is open nearly the whole of the distance, receiving the refuse animal and vegetable matter of the places through which it passes; nevertheless, the water of the New River is much purer than the Thames. The drop of water containing the objects represented in the engraving (Fig. 3) was taken from a cistern near the New River Head. The specimen is magnified 140 diameters.

The objects represented show that no one would from choice drink either of these waters, or use them for culinary purposes. All the sources from which the daily supply of water for upwards of two millions of human beings is obtained are objectionable, containing matter disagreeable to the taste, sight, and smell, and prejudicial to health.

3. Method of Purifying Water.—Although various contrivances have been proposed for the purpose of effecting this desirable object, yet it must be acknowledged that most of them have signally failed, and that the use of Purified water is adopted by comparatively few, the causes of which may be ascribed to the imperfection of the means employed, the trouble and expense of the methods, and the deficient supply of Pure water yielded by all the ordinary Filters.

Natural stone has for a long time been used as a filtering agent, but the frequent inequality of its texture, and its liability to become choked, have much limited its employment; layers of sand often form the basis of a Filter, but when so constructed, the Filters are apt to become deranged in their action, choked with filth, rendered worse than useless, and with great difficulty restored to a useful condition.

The discovery of Mr. Ransome's Artificial Stone, which can be made of any degree of porosity, of complete uniformity of texture throughout, and can be moulded of any required shape and size, and which possesses the advantage of being exceedingly cheap, has at length enabled Filters to be formed which possess all the advantages which can be desired, and by means of which an almost unlimited supply of filtered water can be obtained without trouble, and with certainty and rapidity.

The stone itself, the basis of the Filters, consists of the fine particles of pure sand, united together by means of glass, which is first added to the sand in a liquid state, and after the stone has been moulded, is reduced to a solid form by means of heat. Stone is thus produced of any degree of porosity, depending on the fineness or coarseness of the grit. The quality of the material is such as to have obtained for its discoverer the Medal of the Society of Civil Engineers, the Medal of the Great Exhibition, and the encomiums of such competent judges as Cubitt, Buckland, Faraday, De la Bèche, R. Phillips, Ansted, &c. &c.
The various forms of Filters constructed with the Patent Stone, adapted to every purpose, and suitable to all circumstances of life, will be seen in the annexed description.

By its passage through these Filters, water can be readily freed from all the mechanical impurities which it contains, as undissolved animal and vegetable matters; and such is sufficient for the purification of many kinds of water; but for the purpose of removing dissolved matters and any taints which it may contain, other methods are made use of, consisting of the introduction between the plates of stone of a deodorizing and disinfecting substance, the basis of which is animal charcoal, a body which does not act merely by straining or filtration, but which, when properly prepared, has the power of absorbing any noxious matters which it may meet with. Vegetable charcoal has often been made use of in the construction of Filters, but its powers of purifying are very small, and soon exhausted. Such, however, is not the case with the animal charcoal; and we need only refer to the experiments of Dr. Garrod, published in the Transactions of the Medical Society of London, for a proof of its extraordinary powers, and which have been fully confirmed by Dr. Rand, of Philadelphia. It is there shown that the most poisonous vegetable substances are rendered perfectly harmless when mixed with even small quantities of this body. If such is its power when used with deadly and rapid poisons, how much more can it remove the minute quantities of tainted and injurious substances contained in many waters, which more slowly, yet not less certainly, produce injurious effects upon the health?

It is found also that the minute quantities of lead and other metallic impurities contained in water are effectually absorbed by the charcoal. By the use of this agent, which in the Patant Stone Filters can be readily renewed at the most trifling cost, even the most impure waters can be rendered both sweet and wholesome.

div2.p: Before proceeding to describe the shape, size, and price of the Filters and Purifiers manufactured by Mr. Ransome, it will be necessary to explain the difference between a Filter and a Purifier.

When water is obtained from a well that is unconnected with any sewage or stagnant water, it will probably contain living animalculæ, and earthy particles, which make it look dark and turbid, though perfectly free from smell. This water only requires filtering, to make it bright and wholesome. By referring to Fig. 4, in the annexed engraving, the reader will find a representation of a filter. The vessel containing the water is supposed to be transparent. a is the impure water. b, a layer of sand. c, a round flat artificial stone, about one inch thick; this is the filter, through which the water passes. d, the filtered water.
This Filter is very simple, and can never get out of repair, and requires no other cleansing than to remove the sand, when it becomes too dirty to allow the water to pass through it.

The Purifier. Fig. 5.—When water not only contains animalculæ, but also animal and vegetable matter, in a dissolved and putrid state, and has a disagreeable taste and smell, it not only requires filtering, but also purifying, before it is fit to drink, or made use of, in Cooking. Fig. 5 is a representation of Ransome and Co's patent Purifier. The reader must again suppose the vessel to be transparent, to show the interior management of the Purifier. a is the impure water. b, a layer of sand. c, a perforated cover, laid on the sand. d, the chemical disinfectant. e, a filter, a flat porous slab. f, the filtered and purified water.

The reader will perceive that the Purifier differs from the Filter, by the introduction of the chemical disinfectant, between the two round slabs of porous stone. The upper part of the vessel, containing the impure water, can be easily cleansed, by removing the perforated cover, and washing away the dirty sand. The action of the Purifier will be restored, by placing a layer of fresh sand over the flat stone, and placing the perforated cover upon the sand.

This apparatus is especially designed for the perfect restoration of rain, stagnant, or other foul water, to a state of pristine purity, by the
ABSTRACTION OF ALL DELETERIOUS PROPERTIES,
however subtle and minute, held both in solution and suspension, which are so offensive to the taste as well as injurious to the health. The principle of its construction ensures thorough purification and filtration. The water, after passing through the Patent Filtering Stone, is submitted to the action of a chemical disinfectant, and is thus rendered equal in quality to the purest spring water, being bright and sparkling to the eye, and fresh and lively to the palate. Among the principal advantages this apparatus possesses over others designed for the same purpose are the following:—

The water, by passing through the porous stone, is deprived of any remaining matters that may be held in suspension; the chemical disinfectant, therefore, has only to purify the liquid, by the abstraction of any subtle or poisonous element that may be left in solution, and this process it most effectually accomplishes without the risk of being obstructed by foul substances; the liability to derangement from choking is, therefore, out of the question.

The most novel, cheap, and easily applied Filter is the Patent Stone Syphon Filter. Fig. 14 shows their usual shape, but they can be made of any shape or size required. A traveller arriving at any place where the spring water is so hard that it is unfit for use, either for making tea or for mixing spirits—or the soft water so disagreeable to the taste or sight that he dislikes to use it—if he possesses a Syphon Filter, which weighs
about four pounds, and can be easily packed in a travelling trunk, may procure an abundant supply of pure, sparkling, wholesome water, in a few minutes: he has only to order a pail of water to be brought to his apartment, and placed upon a table. Before immersing the circular Filter in the pail, it will be necessary to attach the small gutta percha pipe, having a tap at one end of it, (fig. 16,) to the screw in the centre of the Filter; then, placing the Filter in the pail, let the gutta percha pipe hang over the side of it, so that the tap at the end of the pipe comes below the pail. The pipe thus becomes a syphon, and the water when drawn from the Filter will be found perfectly clear and fit for use.

Fig. 15 exhibits the Syphon Filter in action. A, the unfiltered water; B, the stone filter; C, the union to which the gutta percha pipe, forming the syphon, is screwed; D, the syphon; E, a glass receiving the filtered water.

The air must be drawn from the syphon when it is inserted in the pail by placing the end of the pipe between the lips and inhaling the air for half a second, when the filtered water will rush into the mouth; then turn the tap, and gently hang down the pipe; again turn the tap, and a continuous stream of fresh water will run into the glass, E. The Goblet Filter is another invention for the convenience of travellers by sea or land. The Filter is made in the form of a cup, which is placed in a goblet-shaped vessel of glass or earthenware. The impure water, as served out at sea, A, is poured into the porous stone filter, B; it immediately runs through it, and fills the goblet with filtered water, C; it is drawn from the goblet by means of a small tap. For chemists its use will be found invaluable for many operations in the laboratory, releasing them from the inconvenience that ever attends the use of paper.

THE MILITARY CAMP AT CHOBHAM.—Amongst the novel objects of interest, combined with the portability necessary for military encampment, is a mode of obtaining pure water at the Camp. A filter of porous stone (we believe Ransome's patent) is placed in a barrel. The barrel is then filled from the nearest reservoir with water, which permeates through the stone to the interior, and thence is conveyed, by a conduit pipe, through the barrel; at the exterior of which it terminates in a tap, by which it may be drawn off in any quantity, the filter being always charged with pure water, rendered delightfully cool by the refrigerant body around it.—ILLUSTRATED LONDON NEWS, July 30th, 1853.

RANSOME'S FILTER.—Public attention is being directed to a peculiar kind of Filter patented by Messrs. RANSOME and MAY, of Ipswich. This machine is manufactured in the Patent Stone made by the same firm and which attracted the notice of Chemists in the Great Exhibition of 1851. This material can be made of any degree of porosity, of complete uniformity of texture throughout, and can be moulded of any required shape and size; it consists of the fine particles of pure sand united together by means of glass which is first added to the sand in a liquid state, and after the stone has been moulded is reduced to a solid form by means of heat. The filtration of the water is thus accomplished easily by placing the filter made of this stone in any vessel containing the fluid and attaching to it a pipe with a tap at the end communicating with the outside of the vessel. The advantages of this Filter consist in its simplicity, the perfection of the filtration, the coolness of the filtered fluid, and the cheapness of construction. These Filters seem to possess all the qualities required by lovers of pure water. The Patentees have applied their invention to vessels of all kinds.

div1.head: Testimonial from Dr. GARROD, Physician to University College Hospital.
div1.p: SIR, — I have examined the Filter received from your Establishment, and think it answers admirably all the purposes for which a Filter is required. Its compactness and portability greatly recommend it, arising, I presume, from the employment of artificial stone discs in the place of the ordinary layers of sand. Again, it thoroughly purifies as well as filters, stagnant water being deprived of all noxious qualities, and rendered free from odour or taste. Its powers, however, are not confined simply to the removal of ordinary taint, for it also separates poisonous principles, and renders the filtered fluid harmless. Understanding that animal charcoal was one of the materials employed in its construction, and having previously investigated the powers of this substance, I submitted the Filter to two searching tests:— First, I passed an infusion of opium, and then one of rhubarb, through it; in both instances the fluid became perfectly colourless, tasteless, and inodorous, and did not exhibit any trace of these substances when chemically examined. Therefore, should water at any time become poisonous, the use of your Filter will render it innoxious. That it does become so occasionally, we have ample evidence from the symptoms caused by the water of certain countries; and during the late epidemic of cholera, many facts appeared to show a close connexion between the health of a locality and the purity of the water with which it was supplied.—In all cases the advantage of using pure water must be obvious to every person.

closer.signed:
A. B. GARROD, M.D.,
Professor of Materia Medica and Therapeutics at University College,
and Physician to University College Hospital.

div1.head: Testimonial from Dr. JOHN SNOW.
div1.p: THERE are many facts which prove that impurities in the water used for drinking and for culinary purposes have quite as much influence in causing disease, especially of an epidemic character, as have impurities of the air. It is consequently of great importance that almost every family should be provided with a good Filter, since the water, not only of rivers, but also that of wells, is liable to become contaminated. I have used one of Ransome's Patent Water Purifiers for some time, and am highly satisfied with its action. Besides rendering the water perfectly clear, by the separation of all the particles, however minute, that are suspended in it, this Filter also removes organic matter which is held in solution.

closer.signed:
(Signed) JOHN SNOW, M.D.,
Author of a Work on the Communication of Cholera.

div1.p: Novel Filterer.—An ingenious, novel, and very efficacious method of filtering water has lately been contrived. The filter is a cylinder, formed of a porous stone of a peculiar quality; through this substance nothing passes but the pure element, all foreign and deleterious substances being stopped. The simplicity of the construction of this instrument or machine is its great recommendation, and in that respect it is superior to the numerous kinds of filters generally employed, which, though they have their benefits, are almost all, to a certain degree, complex or defective. This simplicity of contrivance insures the lasting properties of the filter; indeed, it would appear that it can receive little or no injury from wear and tear, neither does it require to be continually cleansed or put to rights, as it, in a manner, purifies itself at the same time that it purifies the water that passes through it.

div1.head: Testimonial of JABEZ HOGG, Esq., Surgeon.
div1.p: DEAR SIR,—You ask me for my opinion upon the “Porous Stone Filter” I have had in use; this I readily give, for the following reasons:—That my attention has been drawn to the water-supply of London for several years past, both chemically and microscopically. The latter examinations have indeed often surprised me from the very large quantity of living animalculæ and the debris of dead matters I have constantly found present in the water taken from my cistern—a small quantity of which will afford an evening's amusement for my children, and a most convincing argument to my friends of the injury that must arise to health from the daily use of water from so corrupt a source. I have likewise been at some trouble to investigate the supplies and the storing of water in Emigrant ships. Mrs. Chisholm has pointed out to me the deplorable results that have been known to ensure on shipboard from the want of wholesome drinking water. These, with other circumstances, have led me to inquire into the various modes of purification adopted, and I must say that all filterers hitherto have more or less disappointed me, from their being liable to become so quickly foul and choked up when large quantities of water are sent through them, and from the neglect of those in charge of them not keeping up a daily and fresh supply, and at the same time rejecting and clearing away the refuse of former days.

When my attention was first directed to your “Patent Porous Stone Filter,” I saw immediately that this would remedy most of the evils complained of, not alone from its chemical composition (which is very good), but also from the mode of using it, namely, that of fixing it into the water cistern, and thereby causing the whole supply of the house to pass through it, arresting the danger on the very threshold. I must say that the trial has fully realized my expectations. One instance of its usefulness is most agreeably exemplified in the kitchen-boiler, which we all know must be constantly cleaned out to remove the large deposit of carbonate of lime, with other organic matters, thus rendering the water unsightly and unsuited for use; this is now always clear and wholesome, and the damage done to the boiler by these deposits prevented. I have quite satisfied myself that the water is also rendered not only clean but pure; after standing-by some of it for a week, I have at the end of that time examined it with the microscope, and have not found any living animalculæ. I have purposely mixed deleterious substances with water, and then passed it through the filter, when I have been unable to detect them, even by the aid of chemical re-agents—the water proving perfectly sweet, and fit for drinking. This is a matter of no small importance, since careful investigators have clearly traced the ravages of fearful epidemics to the contaminated state of the water used in some localities.

I believe no natural stone exists which possesses these advantages to so great an extent, and that none of the contrivances hitherto used for filtering are equally simple and efficacious. In the Great Exhibition of 1851, among the objects that challenged the attention of the thousands of visitors was the Iris Fountain, about eighteen inches in diameter, from the centre of which a jet shot up more than three feet in height, the water then separated and fell—not in a descending stream, but in a sparkling succession of liquid particles, forming a feathery spray, upon which, when the light was favourable, appeared a beautiful miniature rainbow. It was from this circumstance that the jet d'eau obtained its name.

This elegant decoration may now be obtained at the Depôt, 71, Baker Street, Portman Square, London. The Iris Fountain is peculiarly adapted, in its variety of forms, for dining, drawing, and ball rooms, or for the boudoir and conservatory. Perfumed waters may, by the agency of this fountain, be brought into continuous contact with the atmosphere, producing a refreshing and luxurious effect. It is portable, simple in its mechanism, and perfect in itself: it is not liable to derangement. The Iris Fountain will continue playing upwards of three hours, and when the jet becomes languid, any person can restore its perfect action in two seconds, by merely turning it round as it stands upon the table or pedestal, when it will again play for three hours. This simple means of revival may be repeated with the same effect at pleasure.

The Iris Fountain is complete in itself, requiring no fittings or water pipes for supply or waste whatever; the water once supplied to the fountain, and ejected by its action, returns to be again thrown out; the only loss of water, therefore, will be by evaporation.
